results.title: The Chain of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Vanishing Wilderness”.
Man is destroying his environment when he uses chemical instead of biological pesticide controls. Man is the end link in the chain of life and is limiting his own survival when he destroys other links in that chain.

results.title: The Chain gang
results.creator_credit: English, Scottish and Australian Bank Film Unit and A Zegenhagen
results.brief_description: Training film for bank tellers, aiming to foster customer loyalty by making the customer feel welcome, important and at ease. The chain of branches is 500 strong and each individual bank throughout Australia is important as a link in the chain. Personal attention is shown to be vital in the formation of the customer’s image of the bank.

results.title: The Century of cinema: Russia and Poland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
The Russian Idea (Producers, Leonid Vereschagin, Valery Ruzin, director, Sergei Selyanov): Philosopher Nikolai Berdyaev asserted that the Russian cinema consisted of a series of opposing forces - despotism and anarchy, cruelty and kindness, mysticism and atheism, servitude and riot. In an attempt to reach beyond their contradictory nature, the Russian people would create perfect worlds attainable only through the destruction of dissonant reality. The desire for revolution has been termed ‘The Russian Idea’. In this controversial documentary, Sergei Selyanov seeks evidence of this ‘idea’ in Russian cinema. Beginning with an extensive depiction of the social Utopianism of Twenties Russia, fragments of films are juxtaposed alongside each other in order to reflect hopeful and fantastic pictures of a bright new future. In contrast to this is the realistic atmosphere of Moscow depicted in Boris Barnet’s films and their images of the struggles that people were willing to endure in order to realise their utopian ideals. Selyanov believes that in the Thirties ‘The Russian Idea’ degenerated on the screen into the ugly official Utopia of Stalinism - a theme which permeated everything until Krushchev came to power, when cinema gradually returned to the sources and depths of the national character. “100 years of Polish cinema” (Producers, Ryszard Sraszewski, Krzysztof Kieslowski, Irena Strzalkowska, director, Pawel Lozinski): Based on an original idea by Krzysztof Kieslowski, Pawel Lozinski’s documentary differs from other films in the Century of Cinema series in its unique approach to cinema as perceived by the audience. In interviews with a dramatic range of individuals - children, the elderly, the visually impaired - Lozinski attempts to evoke the magic and power of Polish cinema through collective memory. Through these personal monologues it is possible to see what has moved a Polish audience over the past century. There are no filmmakers interviewed in this documentary, no technicians or critics or financiers - simply those for whom the movies are made. In Polish in with English subtitles.

results.title: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Nagisa Oshima, Park Ki-Yong, Eiko Oshima and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
‘Nagisa Oshima’s 100 Years of Japanese Cinema’ is a fascinating personal journey through the history of Japanese film-making which moves from the end of the 19th century through to the mid-90s. A rare chance to see stills and excerpts from classic films made in Japan. Oshima comments on his own films as well as the Japanese film industry and its relationship to the country’s political and social changes. Films by great Japanese directors from Muzoguchi, Ozu, Kurosawa, ‘Beat’ Takeshi Kitano, Manga films and Japanese documentary makers are all discussed. ‘The Cinema On The Road’ is a wonderful documentary which uses the road movie genre as a device to explore the history and current contexts of Korean Cinema. With interesting footage of the Korean landscape and cities, as well as interviews with directors and excerpts and stills from films, this is a fascinating insight into a national cinema which is rarely seen. Both documentaries are in English with interviews and film excerpts in Japanese and Korean with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea

results.title: The century of cinema. Volume 2 (USA)
results.creator_credit: Florence Dauman, Michael Henry Wilson, Martin Scorsese and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Scorsese’s enthusiasm for his country’s film history is infectious and it permeates this second volume of the Century of Cinema. Divided into three sections, “A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese through American cinema” doesn’t attempt to be objective or all inclusive. Instead Scorsese leads us through a fascinating tour of American cinema, conjuring interesting connections and unearthing lesser known gems. Includes interviews with Gregory Peck, Clint Eastwood, Billy Wilder, John Ford, King Vidor, Howard Hawks, Francis Coppola, Brian De Palma, Fritz Lang, Andre de Toth, Douglas Sirk, Nicholas Ray, Samuel Fuller, Orson Welles, Elia Kazan, Arthur Penn and John Cassavetes.

results.title: The Century of cinema. Volume 1 (UK, Ireland, Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
White fellas dreaming. Written and directed by George Miller. Produced by George Miller and Doug Mitchell. 1996. Miller presents an entertaining journey through Australian cinema. Cinema is discussed in relation to the changing nature of society and how Australians have constructed and deconstructed a national cinema through celluloid. A must see for anyone interested in Australian cinema heritage. “Cinema of unease. A personal journey by Sam Neill”. Written and directed by Sam Neill and Judy Rymer. Produced by Paula Jalfon and Grant Campbell. 1995. New Zealand cinema is a recent addition to the realm of national cinema, experiencing a significant growth in the previous two decades. Neill visits the land he migrated to and his experience as a performer and a viewer. “Typically British”. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Frears explores the notion of the incompatibility of ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ in a personal way to present the outstanding films and film-makers of Britain.

results.brief_description: ‘The Century of cinema’ is a series of highly personal documentaries made by leading film directors throughout the world. It was executive produced by Colin MacCabe and Bob Last for BFI TV and Channel Four Television in association with a world-wide alliance of broadcasters and distributors.

results.title: The Centre
results.creator_credit: Paul Rotha, Films of Fact and J.B. Holmes
results.brief_description: The Pioneer Health Centre in Peckham was one of the first community health centres in England. This film shows the facilities and follows a family who join the Centre. The father and young son enjoy the Centre’s activities, however, the mother is less impressed because the Centre’s thorough medical check revealed that she needs to undergo surgery. The mother is gradually won over as she regains her health through the Centre’s facilities.

results.title: The Centigram beam balance
results.brief_description: Instructional film showing: use of measuring instruments; preparation of balance for use; levelling and adjusting the beam; use of weights; technique of weighing; checking the weight; packing up weight and closing the balance case.
